quizzes.question: Which choice is the correct command to use when creating a table?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]SQL Tables[/h1]

A single database can house hundreds of tables, each playing its own unique role in the database schema. 

SQL tables are comprised of table rows and columns. Table columns are responsible for storing many different types of data, including numbers, texts, dates, and even files.

The [b]CREATE TABLE[/b] statement is used to create a new table.
[note]Creating a basic table involves naming the table and defining its columns and each column's data type.[/note]

quizzes.question: Type in the keyword used as type for integer numbers.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Creating a Table[/h1]

The basic syntax for the CREATE TABLE statement is as follows: [code format="sql"][b]CREATE TABLE[/b] table_name
(
column_name1 data_type(size),
column_name2 data_type(size),
column_name3 data_type(size),
....
columnN data_type(size)
);[/code]
- The [b]column_names [/b]specify the names of the columns we want to create.
- The [b]data_type [/b]parameter specifies what type of data the column can hold. For example, use [b]int [/b]for whole numbers.
- The [b]size [/b]parameter specifies the maximum length of the table's column.
[note]Note the [b]parentheses [/b]in the syntax.[/note]

quizzes.question: Type in the keyword used as type for a text in the lesson:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Creating a Table[/h1]

Assume that you want to create a table called "Users" that consists of four columns: UserID, LastName, FirstName, and City.

Use the following CREATE TABLE statement: [code format="sql"]CREATE TABLE Users
(
   UserID [b]int[/b],
   FirstName [b]varchar[/b](100), 
   LastName [b]varchar[/b](100),
   City [b]varchar[/b](100)
); [/code]
[note][b]varchar [/b]is the datatype that stores characters. You specify the number of characters in the parentheses after the type. So in the example above, our fields can hold max [b]100 [/b]characters long text.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to define a column named ''some_column'' of type varchar with a size of 50.
[!raw!]
some_column {0}({1})
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Data Types[/h1]

[b]Data types[/b] specify the type of data for a particular column.

If a column called "LastName" is going to hold names, then that particular column should have a "varchar" (variable-length character) data type.

The most common data types:
[b][u]Numeric[/u][/b]
[b]INT [/b]-A normal-sized integer that can be signed or unsigned.
[b]FLOAT[/b](M,D) - A floating-point number that cannot be unsigned. You can optionally define the display length (M) and the number of decimals (D).
[b]DOUBLE[/b](M,D) - A double precision floating-point number that cannot be unsigned. You can optionally define the display length (M) and the number of decimals (D). 

[b][u]Date and Time[/u][/b]
[b]DATE [/b]- A date in [i]YYYY-MM-DD[/i] format.
[b]DATETIME [/b]- A date and time combination in YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS format.
[b]TIMESTAMP [/b]- A timestamp, calculated from midnight, January 1, 1970
[b]TIME [/b]- Stores the time in HH:MM:SS format.

[b][u]String Type[/u][/b]
[b]CHAR[/b](M) - Fixed-length character string. Size is specified in parenthesis. Max 255 bytes.
[b]VARCHAR[/b](M) - Variable-length character string. Max size is specified in parenthesis.
[b]BLOB - [/b]"Binary Large Objects" and are used to store large amounts of binary data, such as images or other types of files. 
[b]TEXT [/b]- Large amount of text data.
[note]Choosing the correct data type for your columns is the key to good database design.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the missing parts to make the ''id'' column a primary key.
[!raw!]
{0} {1} (id)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Primary Key[/h1]

The [b]UserID [/b]is the best choice for our Users table's primary key.
Define it as a primary key during table creation, using the [b]PRIMARY KEY[/b] keyword. [code format="sql"]CREATE TABLE Users
(
   UserID int,
   FirstName varchar(100),
   LastName varchar(100),
   City varchar(100),
  [b] PRIMARY KEY(UserID)[/b]
); [/code]
[note]Specify the column name in the parentheses of the PRIMARY KEY keyword.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to create a table with three columns: ''id'' as a primary key, username and password of type varchar.
[!raw!]
{0} test (
 id {1},
 username {2}(30),
 password varchar(20),
 {3} (id)
);
